description: sensible +‎ -ity, from Middle French sensibilité, and its source, Latin sēnsibilitās.

entries.meaning: The ability to sense, feel or perceive; responsiveness to sensory stimuli; sensitivity. [from 15th c.]
examples: The high sensibility of the divided ring electrometer renders this test really very easy […].

entries.meaning: Emotional or artistic awareness; keen sensitivity to matters of feeling or creative expression. [from 17th c.]
examples: By poetic ethic I am speaking about the intention to act on, and incorporate into a narrative configuration, values and beliefs that promote a poetic ontology and a poetic sensibility.

entries.meaning: (now rare, archaic) Excessive emotional awareness; the fact or quality of being overemotional. [from 18th c.]
(in the plural) An acute awareness or feeling. [from 18th c.]
examples: I apologize if I offended your sensibilities, but that's the truth of the matter.

entries.meaning: (obsolete) The capacity to be perceived by the senses. [15th–17th c.]
